marc:datafield.marc:subfield: Legal documents consisting of a land survey, land grants, a legal case, a power of attorney, and a certificate of citizenship for Thomas Graves of Georgia.
Letter from Henry Bromfield, Jr., of London to Banks commenting on the heavy demands from America for British goods.
French government representative in Saint Domingue (now Haiti). Later negotiated the sale of Louisiana Territory to the United States.

Letter, intended recipient unknown but possibly the Chevalier de Brun, written from Port-au-Prince, Saint Domingue, where Barbé-Marbois served as intendant for the French government. Concerns contraband and commercial relations between the French West Indies and the United States.

The collection consists of letters of the children of Grief Barksdale (1774-1850), merchant and planter of Rough Creek, Charlotte County, Virginia, including Charlotte (1813-1886), Claiborne (1820-1883), Nancy (1829-1904), and Susan (1832- 1863). One letter form an unnamed correspondent includes a statement from C. R. Barksdale to Joseph B. Friend concerning the sale of tobacco for Friend, which was negotiated by C. R. Barksdale and Co. Additional materials include business and personal correspondence of Charlotte's husband, Samuel Hannah (1796-1859), of Charleston, Kanawha County; Charlotte County; and Lynchburg. Topics include business conditions and interests, especially relating to tobacco and cotton; slave hiring in Richmond, 1827; schooling of the Barksdale children; and conditions in Arkansas, 1870. Two letters from Hannah's agent in Liverpool, England, 1828-1829, concern British import duties.
Governor of Virginia (1812-1815), U.S. Senator, and U.S. Secretary of War; from Orange County, Va.
Papers containing references to Indian affairs, the Richmond fire of 1811, a proposed canal between the Potomac and Rappahannock rivers, and pension payments.
N.C. and H. C. Baker memorandum book and letter,

Memorandum book, 1822, of N.C. Baker describing his travels to Philadelphia, New York and New Haven. Discussed are religious concerns, shipping, hunting, an election, a circus, tomatoes, books and a fire. A letter by H.C. Baker, 1900, mentions works on the assassination of Abraham Lincoln.
Chiefly papers of the Bedford, Pa. law firm of Murdock and Barclay, with several references to Pennsylvania and national politics.
Cataloged from Guide and card catalog.
North Carolina resident and postal carrier of Stokes County. Joseph Banner carried the mail from Germantown to Salem.
Letters concerning the postal service. Included is one letter from Augustine H. Shepard, a member of Congress from North Carolina.
Daniel Baker was a Virginia carpenter (Frederick County).
Business letters of Baker, a journeyman carpenter, commenting on labor conditions in the 1850s and family letters from relatives in Kentucky, Missouri, and Ohio.
New York resident, author, Secretary of the Navy, and historian.

Fifteen letters (transcripts) to David L. Swain, president of the University of North Carolina, relating to the history of the state. Topics include the Regulators, Loyalists, Mecklenburg Declaration, Governors William Tryon and Alexander Martin, and Hermon Husbands and Edmund Fanning. Original items include a letter to C.C. Jones on the employment of women and children in Germany and a note, 1885, of thanks for Jones's article on Richard H. Wilde; a letter from H.C. Van Schaack regarding the publication of his pamphlet on Henry Cruger; and notes relating to appointments by Bancroft as Secretary of the Navy, and to payment from publishers.
Cataloged from Guide. The Swain letters are transcripts from originals located at the Wilson Library at the University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill.
University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill
Quaker, resident of Thorntown (Boone County), Ind.

Family correspondence between Quaker settlers in Indiana and relatives in Randolph County, N.C., describing crops, opportunities in the West, commodity prices, and personal matters. Some items mention the Woody family which moved from Guilford County, N.C., to Boone County, Ind. Also included are papers relating to the James Sluder family of Ashe County, N.C., and La Grange, Randolph County. Among the writers is Levi Cox of Randolph County.

Family letters of Bain, his wife, and children to his daughter, Mollie Bain Bitting of Germantown, North Carolina. Topics include Bain's Masonic interests, difficulties with slaves, the "Black Republicanism" of the North, a speech by Stephen A. Douglas (1860), hopes for a strong Confederacy, and meetings of the legislature. Also includes a letter to Mrs. Bitting from a friend in Petersburg, Va., describing the new public buildings there, and a letter to Lewis Bitting from a friend in Georgia describing his drugstore business.
Personal letters relating to John Barker and his family.
Cataloged from Guide and card catalog.
Teacher and resident of Marion County, Missouri.
Personal letters of James Balthrope, a teacher, to William Engle describing life in northern Missouri.
Letters from Baker, a private in Longstreet's Corps of the Confederate Army, to his wife. The letters are concerned chiefly with inquiries about home conditions.
Union Soldier, Congressman, and Governor of Massachusetts, 1858-1861.
Partial letters (20 pages total) from Nathaniel Prentiss Banks in New Orleans to "Anne." Also included is part of a report to Major General Halleck on "La Bataille des Mouchoirs."
Confederate soldier, from Surry County, N.C.
Letters describing his experiences in active service in the Confederate Army at Weldon, N.C., in 1864, and his stay in the General Hospital in Richmond, Va., where he died in 1865.

Entries primarily relate to Bancroft's daily chores and activities, including those of a religious nature. Provides a detailed account of her sister Carrie's death. The family lived in Vermont during the period covered by the diary; by April 1866 they had moved to Bristol, Vt. Also includes a note on the diary by her father, George C. Bancroft, a minister.
Foot peddler's license issued by the Baltimore City Clerk of the Court of Common Pleas to Josiah H. Benton. The license was valid for a period of 8 months.
Merchant of Richmond and Stanford (Madison Co.), Kentucky.
Correspondence of Thomas C. Ball chiefly from relatives in Missouri and Texas, describing social life and customs.
Personal and business letters. Topics include the illness of Barker's wife; New Garden Academy, New Garden, N.C.; and a publication of the Society of Friends.
Letters from George Becker and C.M. Evarts to Bamberger concerning legal cases.
